Universal Source Coding for Monotonic and Fast Decaying Monotonic Distributions111Supported by NSF Grant CCF-0347969. Part of the material in this manuscript was accepted for presentation in the IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory, Nice, France, June, 2007.

Gil I. Shamir
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
University of Utah
Salt Lake City, UT 84112, U.S.A

Abstract

We study universal compression of sequences generated by monotonic distributions. We show that for a monotonic distribution over an alphabet of size k𝑘k, each probability parameter costs essentially 0.5​log⁡(n/k3)0.5𝑛superscript𝑘30.5\log(n/k^{3}) bits, where n𝑛n is the coded sequence length, as long as k=o​(n1/3)𝑘𝑜superscript𝑛13k=o(n^{1/3}). Otherwise, for k=O​(n)𝑘𝑂𝑛k=O(n), the total average sequence redundancy is O​(n1/3+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits overall. We then show that there exists a sub-class of monotonic distributions over infinite alphabets for which redundancy of O​(n1/3+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits overall is still achievable. This class contains fast decaying distributions, including many distributions over the integers and geometric distributions. For some slower decays, including other distributions over the integers, redundancy of o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n) bits overall is achievable, where a method to compute specific redundancy rates for such distributions is derived. The results are specifically true for finite entropy monotonic distributions. Finally, we study individual sequence redundancy behavior assuming a sequence is governed by a monotonic distribution. We show that for sequences whose empirical distributions are monotonic, individual redundancy bounds similar to those in the average case can be obtained. However, even if the monotonicity in the empirical distribution is violated, diminishing per symbol individual sequence redundancies with respect to the monotonic maximum likelihood description length may still be achievable.

Index Terms: monotonic distributions, universal compression, average redundancy, individual redundancy, large alphabets, patterns.

1 Introduction

The classical setting of the universal lossless compression problem [5], [8], [9] assumes that a sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} of length n𝑛n that was generated by a source 𝜽𝜽\theta is to be compressed without knowledge of the particular 𝜽𝜽\theta that generated xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} but with knowledge of the class ΛΛ\Lambda of all possible sources 𝜽𝜽\theta. The average performance of any given code, that assigns a length function L​(⋅)𝐿⋅L(\cdot), is judged on the basis of the redundancy function Rn​(L,𝜽)subscript𝑅𝑛𝐿𝜽R_{n}\left(L,\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right), which is defined as the difference between the expected code length of L​(⋅)𝐿⋅L\left(\cdot\right) with respect to (w.r.t.) the given source probability mass function Pθsubscript𝑃𝜃P_{\theta} and the n𝑛nth-order entropy of Pθsubscript𝑃𝜃P_{\theta} normalized by the length n𝑛n of the uncoded sequence. A class of sources is said to be universally compressible in some worst sense if the redundancy function diminishes for this worst setting. Another approach to universal coding [29] considers the individual sequence redundancy R^n​(L,xn)subscript^𝑅𝑛𝐿superscript𝑥𝑛\hat{R}_{n}\left(L,x^{n}\right), defined as the normalized difference between the code length obtained by L​(⋅)𝐿⋅L(\cdot) for xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} and the negative logarithm of the maximum likelihood (ML) probability of the sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, where the ML probability is within the class ΛΛ\Lambda. We thereafter refer to this negative logarithm as the ML description length of xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. The individual sequence redundancy is defined for each sequence that can be generated by a source 𝜽𝜽\theta in the given class ΛΛ\Lambda.

Classical literature on universal compression [5], [8], [9], [23], [29] considered compression of sequences generated by sources over finite alphabets. In fact, it was shown by Kieffer [15] (see also [13]) that there are no universal codes (in the sense of diminishing redundancy) for sources over infinite alphabets. Later work (see, e.g., [21], [25]), however, bounded the achievable redundancies for identically and independently distributed (i.i.d.) sequences generated by sources over large and infinite alphabets. Specifically, while it was shown that the redundancy does not decay if the alphabet size is of the same order of magnitude as the sequence length n𝑛n or greater, it was also shown that the redundancy does decay for alphabets of size o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n). 222For two functions f​(n)𝑓𝑛f(n) and g​(n)𝑔𝑛g(n), f​(n)=o​(g​(n))𝑓𝑛𝑜𝑔𝑛f(n)=o(g(n)) if ∀c,∃n0for-all𝑐subscript𝑛0\forall c,\exists n_{0}, such that, ∀n>n0for-all𝑛subscript𝑛0\forall n>n_{0}, f​(n)<c​g​(n)𝑓𝑛𝑐𝑔𝑛f(n)<cg(n); f​(n)=O​(g​(n))𝑓𝑛𝑂𝑔𝑛f(n)=O(g(n)) if ∃c,n0𝑐subscript𝑛0\exists c,n_{0}, such that, ∀n>n0for-all𝑛subscript𝑛0\forall n>n_{0}, 0≤f​(n)≤c​g​(n)0𝑓𝑛𝑐𝑔𝑛0\leq f(n)\leq cg(n); f​(n)=Θ​(g​(n))𝑓𝑛Θ𝑔𝑛f(n)=\Theta(g(n)) if ∃c1,c2,n0subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝑛0\exists c_{1},c_{2},n_{0}, such that, ∀n>n0for-all𝑛subscript𝑛0\forall n>n_{0}, c1​g​(n)≤f​(n)≤c2​g​(n)subscript𝑐1𝑔𝑛𝑓𝑛subscript𝑐2𝑔𝑛c_{1}g(n)\leq f(n)\leq c_{2}g(n).

While there is no universal code for infinite alphabets, recent work [20] demonstrated that if one considers the pattern of a sequence instead of the sequence itself, universal codes do exist in the sense of diminishing redundancy. A pattern of a sequence, first considered, to the best of our knowledge, in [1], is a sequence of indices, where the index ψisubscript𝜓𝑖\psi_{i} at time i𝑖i represents the order of first occurrence of letter xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} in the sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. Further study of universal compression of patterns [20], [21], [26], [28] provided various lower and upper bounds to various forms of redundancy in universal compression of patterns. Another related study is that of compression of data, where the order of the occurring data symbols is not important, but their types and empirical counts are [30]-[31].

This paper considers universal compression of data sequences generated by distributions that are known a-priori to be monotonic. Hence, the order of probabilities of the source symbols is known in advance to both encoder and decoder and can be utilized as side information to improve universal compression performance. Monotonic distributions are common for distributions over the integers, including the geometric distribution and others. Such distributions do occur in image compression problems (see, e.g., [18], [19]), and in other applications that compress residual signals. A specific application one can consider for the results in this paper is compression of the list of last or first names in a given city of a given population. One can usually find some monotonicity for such a distribution in the given population, which both encoder and decoder may be aware of a-priori. For example, the last name “Smith” can be expected to be much more common than the last name “Shannon”. Another example is the compression of a sequence of observations of different species, where one has prior knowledge which species are more common, and which are rare. Finally, one can consider compressing data for which side information given to the decoder through a different channel gives the monotonicity order.

Unlike compression of patterns, Foster, Stine, and Wyner, showed in [10] that there are no universal block codes in the standard sense for the complete class of monotonic distributions. The main reason is that there exist such distributions, for which much of the statistical weight lies in symbols that have very low probability, and most of which will not occur in a given sequence. Thus, in practice, even though one has the prior knowledge of the monotonicity of the distribution, this monotonicity is not necessarily retained in an observed sequence. Therefore, actual coding can be very similar to compressing with infinite alphabets, and the additional prior knowledge of the monotonicity is not very helpful in reducing redundancy. Despite that, Foster, Stine, and Wyner demonstrated codes that obtained universal per-symbol redundancy of o​(1)𝑜1o(1) as long as the source entropy is fixed (i.e., neither increasing with n𝑛n nor infinite). However, instead of considering redundancy in the standard sense, the study of monotonic distributions resorted to studying relative redundancy, which bounds the ratio between average assigned code length and the source entropy. This approach dates back to work by Elias [7], Rissanen [22], and Ryabko [24].

The work in [10] studied coding sequences (or blocks) generated by i.i.d. monotonic distributions, and designed codes for which the relative block redundancy could be (upper) bounded. Unlike that work, the focus in [7], [22], and [24] was on designing codes that minimize the redundancy or relative redundancy for a single symbol generated by a monotonic distribution. Specifically, in [22], minimax codes, which minimize the relative redundancy for the worst possible monotonic distribution over a given alphabet size, were derived. In [24], it was shown that redundancy of O​(log⁡log⁡k)𝑂𝑘O(\log\log k), where k𝑘k is the alphabet size, can be obtained with minimax per-symbol codes. Very recent work [16] considered per-symbol codes that minimize an average redundancy over the class of monotonic distributions for a given alphabet size. Unlike [10], all these papers study per-symbol codes. Therefore, the codes designed always pay non-diminishing per-symbol redundancy.

A different line of work on monotonic distributions considered optimizing codes for a known monotonic distribution but with unknown parameters (see [18], [19] for design of codes for two-sided geometric distributions). In this line of work, the class of sources is very limited and consists of only the unknown parameters of a known distribution.

In this paper, we consider a general class of monotonic distributions that is not restricted to a specific type. We study standard block redundancy for coding sequences generated by i.i.d. monotonic distributions, i.e., a setting similar to the work in [10]. We do, however, restrict ourselves to smaller subsets of the complete class of monotonic distributions. First, we consider monotonic distributions over alphabets of size k𝑘k, where k𝑘k is either small w.r.t. n𝑛n, or of O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n). Then, we extend the analysis to show that under minimal restrictions of the monotonic distribution class, there exist universal codes in the standard sense, i.e., with diminishing per-symbol redundancy. In fact, not only do universal codes exist, but under mild restrictions, they achieve the same redundancy as obtained for alphabets of size O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n). The restrictions on this subclass imply that some types of fast decaying monotonic distributions are included in it, and therefore, sequences generated by these distributions (without prior knowledge of either the distribution or of its parameters) can still be compressed universally in the class of monotonic distributions.

The main contributions of this paper are the development of codes and derivation of their upper bounds on the redundancies for coding i.i.d. sequences generated by monotonic distributions. Specifically, the paper gives complete characterization of the redundancy in coding with monotonic distributions over “small” alphabets (k=o​(n1/3)𝑘𝑜superscript𝑛13k=o(n^{1/3})) and “large” alphabets (k=O​(n)𝑘𝑂𝑛k=O(n)). Then, it shows that these redundancy bounds carry over (in first order) to fast decaying distributions. Next, a code that achieves good redundancy rates for even slower decaying monotonic distributions is derived, and is used to study achievable redundancy rates for such distributions. Lower bounds are also presented to complete the characterization, and are shown to meet the upper bounds in the first three cases (small alphabets, large alphabets, and fast decaying distributions). The lower bounds turn out to result from lower bounds obtained for coding patterns. The relationship to patterns is demonstrated in the proofs of those lower bounds. Finally, individual sequences are considered. It is shown that under mild conditions, there exist universal codes w.r.t. the monotonic ML description length for sequences that contain the O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) more likely symbols, even if their empirical distributions are not monotonic.

The outline of this paper is as follows. Section 2 describes the notation and basic definitions. Then, in section 3, lower bounds on the redundancy for monotonic distributions are derived. Next, in Section 4, we propose codes and upper bound their redundancy for coding monotonic distributions over small and large alphabets. These bounds are then extended to fast decaying monotonic distributions in Section 5. Finally, in Section 6, we consider individual sequence redundancy.

3 Lower Bounds

Lower bounds on various forms of the redundancy for the class of monotonic distributions can be obtained with slight modifications of the proofs for the lower bounds on the redundancy of coding patterns in [14], [20], [21], and [26]. The bounds are presented in the following three theorems. For the sake of completeness, the main steps of the proofs of the first two theorems are presented in appendices, and the proof of the third theorem is presented below. The reader is referred to [14], [20], [21], [25] and [26] for more details.

Theorem 2

Fix an arbitrarily small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Then, the n𝑛nth-order average universal coding redundancy for coding i.i.d. sequences generated by monotonic distributions with alphabet size k𝑘k is lower bounded by

Rn​(L,𝜽)≥{k−12​n​log⁡n1−εk3−k−12​n​log⁡8​πe3−O​(log⁡kn),for ​k≤12⋅(n1−επ)1/31.5​log⁡e2​π1/3⋅n(1−ε)/3n−O​(log⁡nn),for ​k>12⋅(n1−επ)1/3subscript𝑅𝑛𝐿𝜽cases𝑘12𝑛superscript𝑛1𝜀superscript𝑘3𝑘12𝑛8𝜋superscript𝑒3𝑂𝑘𝑛for 𝑘⋅12superscriptsuperscript𝑛1𝜀𝜋13⋅1.5𝑒2superscript𝜋13superscript𝑛1𝜀3𝑛𝑂𝑛𝑛for 𝑘⋅12superscriptsuperscript𝑛1𝜀𝜋13R_{n}\left(L,\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\geq\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{k-1}{2n}\log\frac{n^{1-\varepsilon}}{k^{3}}-\frac{k-1}{2n}\log\frac{8\pi}{e^{3}}-O\left(\frac{\log k}{n}\right),&\mbox{for }k\leq\frac{1}{2}\cdot\left(\frac{n^{1-\varepsilon}}{\pi}\right)^{1/3}\\ \frac{1.5\log e}{2\pi^{1/3}}\cdot\frac{n^{(1-\varepsilon)/3}}{n}-O\left(\frac{\log n}{n}\right),&\mbox{for }k>\frac{1}{2}\cdot\left(\frac{n^{1-\varepsilon}}{\pi}\right)^{1/3}\end{array}\right. for every code L​(⋅)𝐿⋅L(\cdot) and almost every i.i.d. source 𝛉∈ℳk𝛉subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}_{k}, except for a set of sources Aε​(n)subscript𝐴𝜀𝑛A_{\varepsilon}\left(n\right) whose relative volume in ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k} goes to 00 as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty.

Theorems 1 and 2 give lower bounds on redundancies of coding over monotonic distributions for the class ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}. However, the bounds are more general, and the second region applies to the whole class of monotonic distributions ℳℳ{\cal M}. As in the case of patterns [20], [26], the bounds in (6)-(7) show that each parameter costs at least 0.5​log⁡(n/k3)0.5𝑛superscript𝑘30.5\log(n/k^{3}) bits for small alphabets, and the total universality cost is at least Θ​(n1/3−ε)Θsuperscript𝑛13𝜀\Theta(n^{1/3-\varepsilon}) bits overall for larger alphabets. Unlike the currently known results on patterns, however, we show in Section 4 that for k=O​(n)𝑘𝑂𝑛k=O(n) these bounds are achievable for monotonic distributions. The proofs of Theorems 1 and 2 are presented in Appendix A and in Appendix B, respectively.

Theorem 3 lower bounds the individual minimax redundancy for coding a sequence believed to have an empirical monotonic distribution. The alphabet size is determined by the maximal letter that occurs in the sequence, i.e., k=max⁡{x1,x2,…,xn}𝑘subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛k=\max\left\{x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}\right\}. The ML probability estimate is taken over the class of monotonic distributions, i.e., the empirical probability (standard ML) estimate 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} is not 𝜽^ℳsubscript^𝜽ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}} in case 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} does not satisfy the monotonicity that defines the class ℳℳ{\cal M}. where (a)𝑎(a) follows from including only sequences ynsuperscript𝑦𝑛y^{n} that have a monotonic empirical (i.i.d. ML) distribution in Shtarkov’s sum. Inequality (b)𝑏(b) follows from partitioning the sequences ynsuperscript𝑦𝑛y^{n} into types as done in [21], first by the number of occurring symbols ℓℓ\ell, and then by the empirical distribution. Unlike standard i.i.d. distributions though, monotonicity implies that only the first ℓℓ\ell symbols in ΣΣ\Sigma occur, and thus the choice of ℓℓ\ell out of k𝑘k in the proof in [21] is replaced by 111. Like in coding patterns, we also divide by ℓ!ℓ\ell! because each type with ℓℓ\ell occurring symbols can be ordered in at most ℓ!ℓ\ell! ways, where only some retain the monotonicity. (Note that this step is the reason that step (b)𝑏(b) produces an inequality, because more than one of the orderings may be monotonic if equal occurrence counts occur.) Except the division by ℓ!ℓ\ell!, the remaining steps follow those in [21]. Retaining only the term ℓ=kℓ𝑘\ell=k yields inequality (c)𝑐(c). Inequality (d)𝑑(d) follows from Stirling’s bound

2​π​m⋅(me)m≤m!≤2​π​m⋅(me)m⋅exp⁡{112​m}.⋅2𝜋𝑚superscript𝑚𝑒𝑚𝑚⋅2𝜋𝑚superscript𝑚𝑒𝑚112𝑚\sqrt{2\pi m}\cdot\left(\frac{m}{e}\right)^{m}\leq m!\leq\sqrt{2\pi m}\cdot\left(\frac{m}{e}\right)^{m}\cdot\exp\left\{\frac{1}{12m}\right\}. (21)

Then, (e)𝑒(e) follows from the relation between arithmetic and geometric means, and from expressing the number of types as the number of ordered partitions of n𝑛n into k𝑘k parts (k−1n−1)superscript𝑘1𝑛1\left(\raisebox{-4.0pt}{$\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mbox{\large$n-1$}}}{{k-1}}$}\right). Finally, (f)𝑓(f) follows from applying (21) again and by lower bounding (k−1n−1)superscript𝑘1𝑛1\left(\raisebox{-4.0pt}{$\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mbox{\large$n-1$}}}{{k-1}}$}\right).

The first region in (8) results directly from (20). The behavior is similar to patterns as shown in [1] for this region. As mentioned in [20], to obtain the second region, the bound is maximized by retaining ℓ^=(n1/3​e5/18)/(2​π)1/3^ℓsuperscript𝑛13superscript𝑒518superscript2𝜋13\hat{\ell}=\left(n^{1/3}e^{5/18}\right)/(2\pi)^{1/3} instead of k𝑘k in step (c)𝑐(c) of (20), for every k≥ℓ^𝑘^ℓk\geq\hat{\ell}. The bounds obtained are equal to those obtained for patterns because the first step (a)𝑎(a) in (20) discards all the sequences whose contributions to Shtarkov’s sum are different between patterns and monotonic distributions. A similar step is effectively done deriving the bounds for patterns. The difference is that in the case of patterns, components of Shtarkov’s sum are reduced, but all are retained in the sum, while here, we omit components from the sum, corresponding to sequences with non-monotonic i.i.d. ML estimates. The analysis in [20] that also attains the second region of the bound in (8) is still valid here. It differs from the steps taken above by lower bounding a pattern probability by a larger probability than the ML i.i.d. probability corresponding to the pattern. The bound used in the derivation of Theorem 12 in [20] adds a multiplicative factor to each pattern probability which equals the number of sequences with the same pattern and an equal i.i.d. ML probability. However, this similar effect is included in Shtarkov’s sum for monotonic distributions since all these sequences do have a corresponding i.i.d. ML estimate which is monotonic, and are thus not omitted by step (a)𝑎(a) of the derivation.

The analysis in [14] yields the third region of the bound in (8), since, for k≥n𝑘𝑛k\geq n,

R^n+​(ℳk)subscriptsuperscript^𝑅𝑛subscriptℳ𝑘\displaystyle\hat{R}^{+}_{n}\left({\cal M}_{k}\right) =\displaystyle= 1n​log⁡{∑ynPθ^ℳ​(yn)}1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑛subscript𝑃subscript^𝜃ℳsuperscript𝑦𝑛\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\left\{\sum_{y^{n}}P_{\hat{\theta}_{{\cal M}}}\left(y^{n}\right)\right\} (22)
≥(a)superscript𝑎\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\geq}} 1n​log⁡{∑Ψ​(yn)Pθ^​(yn)}=(b)1.5​n1/3​log⁡en−O​(log⁡nn),superscript𝑏1𝑛subscriptΨsuperscript𝑦𝑛subscript𝑃^𝜃superscript𝑦𝑛1.5superscript𝑛13𝑒𝑛𝑂𝑛𝑛\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\left\{\sum_{\Psi(y^{n})}P_{\hat{\theta}}\left(y^{n}\right)\right\}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{=}}\frac{1.5n^{1/3}\log e}{n}-O\left(\frac{\log n}{n}\right),

where Ψ​(yn)Ψsuperscript𝑦𝑛\Psi(y^{n}) is the pattern of the sequence ynsuperscript𝑦𝑛y^{n}. Inequality (a)𝑎(a) holds because each pattern corresponds to at least one sequence whose ML probability parameter estimates are ordered, i.e., θ^i≥θ^i+1,∀isubscript^𝜃𝑖subscript^𝜃𝑖1for-all𝑖\hat{\theta}_{i}\geq\hat{\theta}_{i+1},\forall i, where the most probable index represents i=1𝑖1i=1, the second most probable index i=2𝑖2i=2, and so on. Note that the sum element on the right hand side is for a probability of a sequence, not a pattern, but the sum is over all patterns. The left hand side also includes sequences for which the probabilities are unordered. Furthermore, exchanging the letters that correspond to two indices with the same occurrence count will not violate monotonicity. Thus the inequality follows. Step (b)𝑏(b) in (22) is taken from [14], where the sum on the left hand side was shown to equal the right hand side. This was true when summing over all patterns with up to n𝑛n indices, thus requiring k≥n𝑘𝑛k\geq n. Note that this requirement does not mean that n𝑛n distinct symbols must occur in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, only that the maximal symbol in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} is n𝑛n or greater. This concludes the proof of Theorem 3. □□\Box

4 Upper Bounds for Small and Large Alphabets

In this section, we demonstrate codes that asymptotically achieve the lower bounds for 𝜽∈ℳk𝜽subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}_{k} and k=O​(n)𝑘𝑂𝑛k=O(n). We begin with a theorem that shows the achievable redundancies, and devote the remainder of the section to describing the codes and deriving upper bounds on their redundancies. The theorem is stated assuming no initial knowledge of k𝑘k. The proof first considers the setting where k𝑘k is known, and then shows how the same bounds are achieved even when k𝑘k is unknown in advance, but as long as it satisfies the conditions.

Theorem 4

Fix an arbitrarily small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Then, there exist a code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}\left(\cdot\right) that achieves redundancy

Rn​(L∗,𝜽)≤{(1+ε)​k−12​n​log⁡n​(log⁡n)2k3,for ​k≤n1/3,(1+ε)​(log⁡n)​(log⁡kn1/3−ε)​n1/3n,for ​n1/3<k=o​(n),(1+ε)​23​(log⁡n)2​n1/3n,for ​n1/3<k=O​(n),subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽cases1𝜀𝑘12𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛2superscript𝑘3for 𝑘superscript𝑛131𝜀𝑛𝑘superscript𝑛13𝜀superscript𝑛13𝑛for superscript𝑛13𝑘𝑜𝑛1𝜀23superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛13𝑛for superscript𝑛13𝑘𝑂𝑛R_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\leq\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{k-1}{2n}\log\frac{n\left(\log n\right)^{2}}{k^{3}},&\mbox{for }k\leq n^{1/3},\\ \left(1+\varepsilon\right)\left(\log n\right)\left(\log\frac{k}{n^{1/3-\varepsilon}}\right)\frac{n^{1/3}}{n},&\mbox{for }n^{1/3}<k=o(n),\\ \left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{2}{3}\left(\log n\right)^{2}\frac{n^{1/3}}{n},&\mbox{for }n^{1/3}<k=O(n),\end{array}\right. (23)

for i.i.d. sequences generated by any source 𝛉∈ℳk𝛉subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}_{k}.

Slightly tighter bounds are possible in the first and second regions and between them. The bounds presented, however, are inclusive for each of the regions. Note that the third region contains the second, but if k=o​(n)𝑘𝑜𝑛k=o(n), a tighter bound is possible in the second region. The code designed to code a sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} is a two part code [23] that quantizes a distribution that minimizes the cost, and uses it to code xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. The total redundancy cost consists of the cost of describing the quantized distribution and the quantization cost. The second is bounded through the quantized true distribution of the sequence, which cannot result in lower cost than that of the chosen distribution (which minimizes the cost). In order to achieve the low costs of the lower bound, the probability parameters are quantized non-uniformly, where the smaller the probability the finer the quantization. This approach was used in [25] and [26] to obtain upper bounds on the redundancy for coding over large alphabets and for coding patterns, respectively. The method used in [25] and [26], however, is insufficient here, because it still results in too many quantization points due to the polynomial growth in quantization spacing. Here, we use an exponential growth as the parameters increase. This general idea was used in [28] to improve an upper bound on the redundancy of coding patterns. Here, however, we improve on the method presented in [28]. Another key step in the proof here is the fact that since both encoder and decoder know the order of the probabilities a-priori, this order need not be coded. It is sufficient to encode the quantized probabilities of the monotonic distribution, and the decoder can identify which probability is associated with which symbol using the monotonicity of the distribution.

Proof of Theorem 4: We start with k≤n1/3𝑘superscript𝑛13k\leq n^{1/3} assuming k𝑘k is known. Let β=1/(log⁡n)𝛽1𝑛\beta=1/(\log n) be a parameter (note, that we can choose other values). Partition the probability space into J1=⌈1/β⌉subscript𝐽11𝛽J_{1}=\left\lceil 1/\beta\right\rceil intervals,

The reason for these relations are the lower limits of the J1subscript𝐽1J_{1} intervals that restrict the number of parameters inside the interval. The restriction is done in order of intervals, so that the used probabilities are subtracted, leading to the series of equations.

n​Rn​(L∗,𝜽)𝑛subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽\displaystyle nR_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right) ≤\displaystyle\leq log⁡k+(1+ε)​k−12​log⁡n​(log⁡n)2k3+5​(log⁡e)​k𝑘1𝜀𝑘12𝑛superscript𝑛2superscript𝑘35𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\log k+\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{k-1}{2}\log\frac{n\left(\log n\right)^{2}}{k^{3}}+5(\log e)k (40)

where we absorb low order terms in ε′superscript𝜀′\varepsilon^{\prime}. Replacing ε′superscript𝜀′\varepsilon^{\prime} by ε𝜀\varepsilon normalizing the redundancy per symbol by n𝑛n, the bound of the first region of (23) is proved.

We now consider the larger values of k𝑘k, i.e., n1/3<k=O​(n)superscript𝑛13𝑘𝑂𝑛n^{1/3}<k=O(n). The idea of the proof is the same. However, we need to partition the probability space to different intervals, the spacing within an interval must be optimized, and the parameters’ description cost must be bounded differently, because now there are more parameters quantized than points in the quantization grid. Define the j𝑗jth interval as

Ij=[n(j−1)​βn2,nj​βn2),1≤j≤J2,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐼𝑗superscript𝑛𝑗1𝛽superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛𝑗𝛽superscript𝑛21𝑗subscript𝐽2I_{j}=\left[\frac{n^{(j-1)\beta}}{n^{2}},\frac{n^{j\beta}}{n^{2}}\right),~{}~{}1\leq j\leq J_{2}, (41)

where J2=⌈2/β⌉=⌈2​log⁡n⌉subscript𝐽22𝛽2𝑛J_{2}=\left\lceil 2/\beta\right\rceil=\left\lceil 2\log n\right\rceil. Again, let kj=|θi∈Ij|k_{j}=|\theta_{i}\in I_{j}| denote the number of probabilities in 𝜽𝜽\theta that are in interval Ijsubscript𝐼𝑗I_{j}. It could be possible to use the intervals as defined in (24), but this would not guarantee bounded redundancy in the rate we require if there are very small probabilities θi≪1/nmuch-less-thansubscript𝜃𝑖1𝑛\theta_{i}\ll 1/n. This choice of α𝛼\alpha also satisfies the assumption of step (c)𝑐(c) in (49). It should be noted that the proof here would give a bound of O​(n1/3+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) up to k=O​(n4/3)𝑘𝑂superscript𝑛43k=O(n^{4/3}). If the intervals in (24) were used for bounded distributions, the coefficients of the last two regions will be reduced by a factor of 222. Additional manipulations on the grid 𝜼𝜼\eta may reduce the coefficients more (see, e.g., [28]).

The proof up to this point assumes that k𝑘k is known in advance. This is important for the code resulting in the bound for the first region because the quantization grid depends on k𝑘k. Specifically, if in building the grid, k𝑘k is underestimated, the description cost of 𝝋𝝋\varphi increases. If k𝑘k is overestimated, the quantization cost will increase. Also, if the code of the second region is used for a smaller k𝑘k, a larger bound than necessary results. To solve this, the optimization that chooses L∗​(xn)superscript𝐿superscript𝑥𝑛L^{*}\left(x^{n}\right) is done over all possible values of k𝑘k (greater than or equal to the maximal symbol occurring in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}), i.e., every greater k𝑘k in the first region, and the construction of the code for the other regions. For every k𝑘k in the first region, a different construction is done, using the appropriate k𝑘k to determine the spacing in each interval. The value of k𝑘k yielding the shortest code word is then used, and O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) additional bits are used at the prefix of the code to inform the decoder which k𝑘k is used. The analysis continues as before. This does not change the redundancy to first order, giving all three regions of the bound in (23), even if k𝑘k is unknown in advance. This concludes the proof of Theorem 4. □□\Box

5 Upper Bounds for Fast Decaying Distributions

This section shows that with some mild conditions on the source distribution, the same redundancy upper bounds achieved for finite monotonic distributions can be achieved even if the monotonic distribution is over an infinite alphabet. The key observation that allows this is that a distribution that decays fast enough will result in only a small number of occurrences of unlikely letters in a sequence. These letters may very likely be out of order, but since there are very few of them, they can be handled without increasing the asymptotic behavior of the coding cost. More precisely, fast decaying monotonic distributions can be viewed as if they have some effective bounded alphabet size, where occurrences of symbols outside this limited alphabet are rare. We present two theorems and a corollary that show how one can upper bound the redundancy obtained when coding with some unknown distribution. The first theorem provides a slightly stronger bound (with smaller coefficient) even for k=O​(n)𝑘𝑂𝑛k=O(n), where the smaller coefficient is attained by improved bounding, that more uniformly weights the quantization cost for minimal probabilities. In the weaker version of the results presented here, if the distribution decays slower and there are more low probability symbols, the redundancy order does increase due to the penalty of identifying these symbols in a sequence. However, we show, consistently with the results in [10], that as long as the entropy of the source is finite, a universal code, in the sense of diminishing redundancy per symbol, does exist. We begin with stating the two theorems and the corollary, then the proofs are presented. The section is concluded with three examples of typical monotonic distributions over the integers, to which the bounds are applied.

5.1 Upper Bounds

We begin with some notation. Fix an arbitrary small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Define m=△mρ=△nρsuperscript△𝑚subscript𝑚𝜌superscript△superscript𝑛𝜌m\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}m_{\rho}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}n^{\rho} as the effective alphabet size, where ρ>ε𝜌𝜀\rho>\varepsilon. (Note that ρ=(log⁡m)/(log⁡n)𝜌𝑚𝑛\rho=(\log m)/(\log n).) Let

ℛn​(m)=△{m−12​log⁡nm3,for​m=o​(n1/3),12⋅(ρ+23)​(ρ+ε−13)​(log⁡n)2​n1/3,otherwise.superscript△subscriptℛ𝑛𝑚cases𝑚12𝑛superscript𝑚3for𝑚𝑜superscript𝑛13⋅12𝜌23𝜌𝜀13superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛13otherwise{\cal R}_{n}(m)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{m-1}{2}\log\frac{n}{m^{3}},&\mbox{for}~{}m=o\left(n^{1/3}\right),\\ \frac{1}{2}\cdot\left(\rho+\frac{2}{3}\right)\left(\rho+\varepsilon-\frac{1}{3}\right)\left(\log n\right)^{2}n^{1/3},&\mbox{otherwise}.\end{array}\right. (51)
Theorem 5

I. Fix an arbitrarily small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Let xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} be generated by an i.i.d. monotonic distribution 𝛉∈ℳ𝛉ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}. If there exists m∗superscript𝑚m^{*}, such that,

∑i>m∗n​θi​log⁡i=o​[ℛn​(m∗)],subscript𝑖superscript𝑚𝑛subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖𝑜delimited-[]subscriptℛ𝑛superscript𝑚\sum_{i>m^{*}}n\theta_{i}\log i=o\left[{\cal R}_{n}\left(m^{*}\right)\right], (52)

then, there exists a code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}(\cdot), such that

Rn​(L∗,𝜽)≤(1+ε)n​ℛn​(m∗)subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽1𝜀𝑛subscriptℛ𝑛superscript𝑚R_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\leq\frac{\left(1+\varepsilon\right)}{n}{\cal R}_{n}\left(m^{*}\right) (53)

for the monotonic distribution 𝛉𝛉\theta.
II. If there exists m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} for which ρ∗=o​(n1/3/(log⁡n))superscript𝜌𝑜superscript𝑛13𝑛\rho^{*}=o\left(n^{1/3}/(\log n)\right), such that,

∑i>m∗θi​log⁡i=o​(1),subscript𝑖superscript𝑚subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖𝑜1\sum_{i>m^{*}}\theta_{i}\log i=o(1), (54)

then, there exists a universal code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}(\cdot), such that

Rn​(L∗,𝜽)=o​(1).subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽𝑜1R_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)=o(1). (55)

Theorem 5 implies that if a monotonic distribution decays fast enough, its effective alphabet size does not exceed O​(nρ)𝑂superscript𝑛𝜌O(n^{\rho}), and, as long as ρ𝜌\rho is fixed, bounds of the same order as those obtained for finite alphabets are achievable. Specifically, very fast decaying distributions, although over infinite alphabets, may even behave like monotonic distributions with o​(n1/3)𝑜superscript𝑛13o\left(n^{1/3}\right) symbols. The condition in (52) merely means that the cost that a code would obtain in order to code very rare symbols, that are larger than the effective alphabet size, is negligible w.r.t. the total cost obtained from other, more likely, symbols. Note that for m=n𝑚𝑛m=n, the bound is tighter than that of the third region of Theorem 4, and a constant of 5/9595/9 replaces 2/3232/3. The second part of the theorem states that if the decay is slow, but the cost of coding rare symbols is still diminishing per symbol, a universal code still exists for such distributions. However, in this case the redundancy will be dominated by coding the rare (out of order) symbols. This result leads to the following corollary:

Corollary 1

As n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty, sequences generated by monotonic distributions with Hθ​(X)=O​(1)subscript𝐻𝜃𝑋𝑂1H_{\theta}(X)=O(1) are universally compressible in the average sense.

Corollary 1 shows that sequences generated by finite entropy monotonic distributions can be compressed in the average with diminishing per symbol redundancy. This result is consistent with the results shown in [10].

While Theorem 5 bounds the redundancy decay rate with two extremes, a more general theorem can be used to provide some best redundancy decay rate that a code can be designed to adapt to for some unknown monotonic distribution that governs the data. As the examples at the end of this section show, the next theorem is very useful for slower decaying distributions.

Theorem 6

Fix an arbitrarily small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Let xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} be generated by an i.i.d. monotonic distribution 𝛉∈ℳ𝛉ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}. Then, there exists a code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}(\cdot), that achieves redundancy

nRn(L∗,𝛉)≤(1+ε)⋅\displaystyle nR_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\leq\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\cdot (56)
minα,ρ:ρ≥α+ε⁡{12⋅(ρ+2​α)​(ρ−α)​(log⁡n)2​nα+5​(log⁡e)​n1−2​α+(1+1ρ)​n​∑i>nρθi​log⁡i}subscript:𝛼𝜌𝜌𝛼𝜀⋅12𝜌2𝛼𝜌𝛼superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛𝛼5𝑒superscript𝑛12𝛼11𝜌𝑛subscript𝑖superscript𝑛𝜌subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖\displaystyle\min_{\alpha,\rho:\rho\geq\alpha+\varepsilon}\left\{\frac{1}{2}\cdot\left(\rho+2\alpha\right)\left(\rho-\alpha\right)(\log n)^{2}n^{\alpha}+5(\log e)n^{1-2\alpha}+\left(1+\frac{1}{\rho}\right)n\sum_{i>n^{\rho}}\theta_{i}\log i\right\}

for coding sequences generated by the source 𝛉𝛉\theta.

We continue with proving the two theorems and the corollary.

Proof : The idea of the proof of both theorems is to separate the more likely symbols from the unlikely ones. First, the code determines the point of separation m=nρ𝑚superscript𝑛𝜌m=n^{\rho}. (Note that ρ𝜌\rho can be greater than 111.) Then, all symbols i≤m𝑖𝑚i\leq m are considered likely and are quantized in a similar manner as in the codes for smaller alphabets. Unlike bounded alphabets, though, a more robust grid is used here to allow larger values of m𝑚m. Coding of occurrences of these symbols uses the quantized probabilities. The unlikely symbols are coded hierarchically. They are first merged into a single symbol, and then are coded within this symbol, where the full cost of conveying to the decoder which rare symbols occur in the sequence is required. Thus, they are presented giving their actual value. As long as the decay is fast enough, the average cost of conveying these symbols becomes negligible w.r.t. the cost of coding the likely symbols. If the decay is slower, but still fast enough, as the case described in condition (54), the coding cost of the rare symbols dominates the redundancy, but still diminishing redundancy can be achieved. In order to determine the best value of m𝑚m for a given sequence, all values are tried and the one yielding the shortest description is used for coding the specific sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}.

Let m≥2𝑚2m\geq 2 determine the number of likely symbols in the alphabet. For a given m𝑚m, define

Sm=△∑i>mθi,superscript△subscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝜃𝑖S_{m}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\sum_{i>m}\theta_{i}, (57)

as the total probability of the remaining symbols. Given 𝜽𝜽\theta, m𝑚m and Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m}, a probability

P​(xn|m,Sm,𝜽)=△[∏i=1mθinx​(i)]⋅Smnx​(x>m)⋅∏i>m(nx​(i)nx​(x>m))nx​(i),superscript△𝑃conditionalsuperscript𝑥𝑛𝑚subscript𝑆𝑚𝜽⋅delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑛𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑛𝑥𝑥𝑚subscriptproduct𝑖𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑥𝑖subscript𝑛𝑥𝑥𝑚subscript𝑛𝑥𝑖P\left(x^{n}|m,S_{m},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\left[\prod_{i=1}^{m}\theta_{i}^{n_{x}(i)}\right]\cdot S_{m}^{n_{x}(x>m)}\cdot\prod_{i>m}\left(\frac{n_{x}(i)}{n_{x}(x>m)}\right)^{n_{x}(i)}, (58)

can be computed for xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, where nx​(i)subscript𝑛𝑥𝑖n_{x}(i) is the occurrence count of symbol i𝑖i in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, and nx​(x>m)subscript𝑛𝑥𝑥𝑚n_{x}(x>m) is the count of all symbols greater than m𝑚m in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. This probability mass function clusters all large symbols (with small probabilities) greater than m𝑚m into one symbol. Then, it uses the ML estimate of each of the large symbols to distinguish among them in the clustered symbol.

For every m𝑚m, we can define a quantization grid 𝝃msubscript𝝃𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}_{m} for the first m𝑚m probability parameters of 𝜽𝜽\theta. The idea is similar to that used for all probability parameters in the proof of Theorem 4. If m=o​(n1/3)𝑚𝑜superscript𝑛13m=o(n^{1/3}), we use 𝝃m=𝝉msubscript𝝃𝑚subscript𝝉𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}_{m}=\mbox{\boldmath$\tau$}_{m}, where 𝝉msubscript𝝉𝑚\mbox{\boldmath$\tau$}_{m} is the grid defined in (27) where m𝑚m replaces k𝑘k. Otherwise, we can use the definition of 𝜼𝜼\eta in (44). However, to obtain tighter bounds for large m𝑚m, we define a different grid for the larger values of m𝑚m following similar steps to those in (41)-(45). First, define the j𝑗jth interval as

(76)

Since (75)-(76) hold for every m>nε𝑚superscript𝑛𝜀m>n^{\varepsilon}, there exists m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} for which the minimal bound is obtained. To bound the redundancy, we choose this m∗superscript𝑚m^{*}. Now, if the condition in (52) holds, then the second term in (75) and (76) is negligible w.r.t. the first term. Absorbing it in a leading ε𝜀\varepsilon, normalizing by n𝑛n, yields the upper bound of (53), and concludes the proof of the Part I of Theorem 5.

For Part II of Theorem 5, we consider the bound of the second region in (76). If there exists ρ∗=o​(n1/3/(log⁡n))superscript𝜌𝑜superscript𝑛13𝑛\rho^{*}=o\left(n^{1/3}/(\log n)\right) for which the condition in (54) holds, then both terms of (76) are of o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n), yielding a total redundancy per symbol of o​(1)𝑜1o(1). The proof of Theorem 5 is concluded. □□\Box

To prove Corollary 1, we use Wyner’s inequality [32], which implies that for a finite entropy monotonic distribution,

∑i≥1θi​log⁡i=Eθ​[log⁡X]≤Hθ​[X].subscript𝑖1subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖subscript𝐸𝜃delimited-[]𝑋subscript𝐻𝜃delimited-[]𝑋\sum_{i\geq 1}\theta_{i}\log i=E_{\theta}\left[\log X\right]\leq H_{\theta}\left[X\right]. (77)

Since the sum on the left hand side of (77) is finite if Hθ​[X]subscript𝐻𝜃delimited-[]𝑋H_{\theta}[X] is finite, there must exist some n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} such that ∑i>n0θi​log⁡i=o​(1)subscript𝑖subscript𝑛0subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖𝑜1\sum_{i>n_{0}}\theta_{i}\log i=o(1). Let n>n0𝑛subscript𝑛0n>n_{0}, then for m∗=nsuperscript𝑚𝑛m^{*}=n and ρ∗=1superscript𝜌1\rho^{*}=1, condition (54) is satisfied. Therefore, (55) holds, and the proof of Corollary 1 is concluded. □□\Box

We now consider only the upper region in (69) with parameters α𝛼\alpha and ρ𝜌\rho taking any valid value. (The code leading to the bound of the upper region can be applied even if the actual effective alphabet size is in the lower region.) We can sum up the contributions of (71), (67), and (74) to (69), absorbing low order terms in ε𝜀\varepsilon. Equation (67) is valid without the middle ε𝜀\varepsilon term as long as ρ≥α+ε𝜌𝛼𝜀\rho\geq\alpha+\varepsilon. Since, in the upper region of m𝑚m, i≥m𝑖𝑚i\geq m is large enough, Elias’ code for the integers can be used costing (1+ε)​log⁡i1𝜀𝑖(1+\varepsilon)\log i to code i𝑖i, with ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 which can be made arbitrarily small. Hence, the leading coefficient of the bound in (74) can be replaced by (1+ε)​(1+1/ρ)1𝜀11𝜌(1+\varepsilon)(1+1/\rho). This yields the expression bounding the redundancy in (56). This expression applies to every valid choice of α𝛼\alpha and ρ𝜌\rho, including the choice that minimizes the expression. Thus the proof of Theorem 6 is concluded. □□\Box

5.2 Examples

We demonstrate the use of the bounds of Theorems 5 and 6 with three typical distributions over the integers. We specifically show that the redundancy rate of O​(n1/3+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀O\left(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}\right) bits overall is achievable when coding many of the typical monotonic distributions, and, in fact, for many distributions faster convergence rates are achievable with the codes provided in proving the theorems above. The assumption that very few unlikely symbols are likely to appear in a sequence generated by a monotonic distribution, which is reflected in the conditions in (52) and (54), is very realistic even in practical examples. Specifically, in the phone book example, there may be many rare names, but only very few of them may occur in a certain city, and the more common names constitute most of any possible phone book sequence.

5.2.1 Fast Decaying Distributions Over the Integers

Consider the monotonic distributions over the integers of the form,

θi=ai1+γ,i=1,2,…,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃𝑖𝑎superscript𝑖1𝛾𝑖12…\theta_{i}=\frac{a}{i^{1+\gamma}},~{}i=1,2,\ldots, (78)

where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0, and a𝑎a is a normalization coefficient that guarantees that the probabilities over all integers sum to 111. It is easy to show by approximating summation by integration that for some m→∞→𝑚m\rightarrow\infty,

Smsubscript𝑆𝑚\displaystyle S_{m} ≤\displaystyle\leq (1+ε)​aγ​mγ1𝜀𝑎𝛾superscript𝑚𝛾\displaystyle\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{a}{\gamma m^{\gamma}} (79)
∑i>mθi​log⁡isubscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i>m}\theta_{i}\log i ≤\displaystyle\leq (1+ε)​a​log⁡mγ​mγ.1𝜀𝑎𝑚𝛾superscript𝑚𝛾\displaystyle\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{a\log m}{\gamma m^{\gamma}}. (80)

Specifically, as long as γ≤2𝛾2\gamma\leq 2 (slow decay), the minimal value of ρ𝜌\rho required to guarantee negligibility of the sum in (52) is greater than 1/3131/3. Using Theorem 5, this implies that for γ≤2𝛾2\gamma\leq 2, the second (upper) region of the upper bound in (53) holds with the minimal choice of ρ∗=2/(3​γ)superscript𝜌23𝛾\rho^{*}=2/(3\gamma). Plugging in this value in the second region of (51) (i.e., in (53)) yields the upper bound shown below for this region. For γ>2𝛾2\gamma>2, 2/(3​γ)<1/323𝛾132/(3\gamma)<1/3. Hence, (52) holds for m∗=o​(n1/3)superscript𝑚𝑜superscript𝑛13m^{*}=o\left(n^{1/3}\right). This means that for the distribution in (78) with γ>2𝛾2\gamma>2, the effective alphabet size is o​(n1/3)𝑜superscript𝑛13o\left(n^{1/3}\right), and thus the achievable redundancy is in the first region of the bound of (53). Thus, even though the distribution is over an infinite alphabet, its compressibility behavior is similar to a distribution over a relatively small alphabet. To find the exact redundancy rate, we balance between the contributions of (66) and (74) in (69). As long as 1−ρ​γ<ρ1𝜌𝛾𝜌1-\rho\gamma<\rho, condition (52) holds, and the contribution of small letters in (74) is negligible w.r.t. the other terms of the redundancy. n​Rn​(L∗,𝜽)𝑛subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽\displaystyle nR_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right) ≤(a)superscript𝑎\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}} (1+ε)​[a​(2​ρ∗+1)γ​n1−ρ∗​γ​log⁡n+nρ∗2​(1−3​ρ∗)​log⁡n]1𝜀delimited-[]𝑎2superscript𝜌1𝛾superscript𝑛1superscript𝜌𝛾𝑛superscript𝑛superscript𝜌213superscript𝜌𝑛\displaystyle\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\left[\frac{a(2\rho^{*}+1)}{\gamma}n^{1-\rho^{*}\gamma}\log n+\frac{n^{\rho^{*}}}{2}\left(1-3\rho^{*}\right)\log n\right] (81)
=(b)superscript𝑏\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{=}} (1+ε)​(a​3+γ1+γγ+1−31+γ2)​n11+γ​log⁡n1𝜀𝑎3𝛾1𝛾𝛾131𝛾2superscript𝑛11𝛾𝑛\displaystyle\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\left(\frac{a\frac{3+\gamma}{1+\gamma}}{\gamma}+\frac{1-\frac{3}{1+\gamma}}{2}\right)n^{\frac{1}{1+\gamma}}\log n

Corollary 2 gives the redundancy rates for all distributions defined in (78). For example, if γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, the redundancy is O​(n1/3​(log⁡n)2)𝑂superscript𝑛13superscript𝑛2O\left(n^{1/3}(\log n)^{2}\right) bits overall with coefficient 2/9292/9. 5.2.2 Geometric Distributions

Geometric distributions given by

θi=p​(1−p)i−1;i=1,2,…,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃𝑖𝑝superscript1𝑝𝑖1𝑖12…\theta_{i}=p\left(1-p\right)^{i-1};~{}~{}i=1,2,\ldots, (83)

where 0<p<10𝑝10<p<1, decay even faster than the distribution over the integers in (78). Thus their effective alphabet sizes are even smaller. This implies that a universal code can have even smaller redundancy than that presented in Corollary 2 when coding sequences generated by a geometric distribution (even if this is unknown in advance, and the only prior knowledge is that 𝜽∈ℳ𝜽ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}). Choosing m=ℓ⋅log⁡n𝑚⋅ℓ𝑛m=\ell\cdot\log n, the contribution of low probability symbols in (74) to (69) can be upper bounded by

2​n​∑i>mθi​(log⁡i+log⁡n)2𝑛subscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖𝑛\displaystyle 2n\sum_{i>m}\theta_{i}\left(\log i+\log n\right) ≤(a)superscript𝑎\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}} 2​n​(1−p)m​log⁡n+O​(n​(1−p)m​log⁡m)2𝑛superscript1𝑝𝑚𝑛𝑂𝑛superscript1𝑝𝑚𝑚\displaystyle 2n(1-p)^{m}\log n+O\left(n(1-p)^{m}\log m\right) (84)
=(b)superscript𝑏\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{=}} 2​n1+ℓ​log⁡(1−p)​(log⁡n)+O​(n1+ℓ​log⁡(1−p)​log⁡log⁡n)2superscript𝑛1ℓ1𝑝𝑛𝑂superscript𝑛1ℓ1𝑝𝑛\displaystyle 2n^{1+\ell\log(1-p)}(\log n)+O\left(n^{1+\ell\log(1-p)}\log\log n\right)

where (a)𝑎(a) follows from computing Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m} using geometric series, and bounding the second term, and (b)𝑏(b) follows from substituting m=ℓ​log⁡n𝑚ℓ𝑛m=\ell\log n and representing (1−p)ℓ​log⁡nsuperscript1𝑝ℓ𝑛(1-p)^{\ell\log n} as nℓ​log⁡(1−p)superscript𝑛ℓ1𝑝n^{\ell\log(1-p)}. As long as ℓ≥1/(−log⁡(1−p))ℓ11𝑝\ell\geq 1/(-\log(1-p)), the expression in (84) is O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n), thus negligible w.r.t. the redundancy upper bound of (53) with m∗=ℓ∗​log⁡n=(log⁡n)/(−log⁡(1−p))superscript𝑚superscriptℓ𝑛𝑛1𝑝m^{*}=\ell^{*}\log n=(\log n)/(-\log(1-p)). Substituting this m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} in (53), we obtain the following corollary:

Corollary 3

Let 𝛉∈ℳ𝛉ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M} be a geometric distribution defined in (83). Then, there exists a universal code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}(\cdot) that has only prior knowledge that 𝛉∈ℳ𝛉ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}, that can achieve universal coding redundancy

Rn​(L∗,𝜽)≤1+ε−2​log⁡(1−p)⋅(log⁡n)2n.subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽⋅1𝜀21𝑝superscript𝑛2𝑛R_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\leq\frac{1+\varepsilon}{-2\log(1-p)}\cdot\frac{(\log n)^{2}}{n}. (85)

Corollary 3 shows that if 𝜽𝜽\theta parameterizes a geometric distribution, sequences governed by 𝜽𝜽\theta can be coded with average universal coding redundancy of O​((log⁡n)2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O\left((\log n)^{2}\right) bits. Their effective alphabet size is O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n), implying that larger symbols are very unlikely to occur. For example, for p=0.5𝑝0.5p=0.5, the effective alphabet size is log⁡n𝑛\log n, and 0.5​(log⁡n)20.5superscript𝑛20.5(\log n)^{2} bits are required for a universal code. For p=0.75𝑝0.75p=0.75, the effective alphabet size is (log⁡n)/2𝑛2(\log n)/2, and (log⁡n)2/4superscript𝑛24(\log n)^{2}/4 bits are required by a universal code.

5.2.3 Slow Decaying Distributions Over the Integers

Up to now, we considered fast decaying distributions, which all achieved the O​(n1/3+ε/n)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀𝑛O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}/n) redundancy rate. We now consider a slowly decaying monotonic distribution over the integers, given by

θi=ai​(log⁡i)2+γ,i=2,3,…,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃𝑖𝑎𝑖superscript𝑖2𝛾𝑖23…\theta_{i}=\frac{a}{i\left(\log i\right)^{2+\gamma}},~{}i=2,3,\ldots, (86)

where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 and a𝑎a is a normalizing factor (see, e.g., [12], [27]). This distribution has finite entropy only if γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 (but is a valid infinite entropy distribution for γ>−1𝛾1\gamma>-1). Unlike the previous distributions, we need to use Theorem 6 to bound the redundancy for coding sequences generated by this distribution. Approximating the sum with an integral, the order of the third term of (56) is

n​∑i>mθi​log⁡i=O​(n(log⁡m)γ).𝑛subscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝜃𝑖𝑖𝑂𝑛superscript𝑚𝛾n\sum_{i>m}\theta_{i}\log i=O\left(\frac{n}{(\log m)^{\gamma}}\right). (87)

In order to minimize the redundancy bound of (56), we define ρ=nℓ𝜌superscript𝑛ℓ\rho=n^{\ell}. For the minimum rate, all terms of (56) must be balanced. To achieve that, we must have

α+2​ℓ=1−2​α=1−γ​ℓ.𝛼2ℓ12𝛼1𝛾ℓ\alpha+2\ell=1-2\alpha=1-\gamma\ell. (88)

The solution is α=γ/(4+3​γ)𝛼𝛾43𝛾\alpha=\gamma/(4+3\gamma), and ℓ=2/(4+3​γ)ℓ243𝛾\ell=2/(4+3\gamma). Substituting these values in the expression of (56), with ρ=nℓ𝜌superscript𝑛ℓ\rho=n^{\ell}, results in the first term in (56) dominating, and yields the following corollary:

Corollary 4

Let 𝛉∈ℳ𝛉ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M} be defined in (86) with γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0. Then, there exists a universal code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}(\cdot) that has only prior knowledge that 𝛉∈ℳ𝛉ℳ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}, that can achieve universal coding redundancy

Rn​(L∗,𝜽)≤(1+ε)​nγ+43​γ+4​(log⁡n)22​n.subscript𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿𝜽1𝜀superscript𝑛𝛾43𝛾4superscript𝑛22𝑛R_{n}\left(L^{*},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right)\leq\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{n^{\frac{\gamma+4}{3\gamma+4}}(\log n)^{2}}{2n}. (89)

Due to the slow decay rate of the distribution in (86), the effective alphabet size is much greater here. For γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, for example, it is nn2/7superscript𝑛superscript𝑛27n^{n^{2/7}}. This implies that very large symbols are likely to appear in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. As γ𝛾\gamma increases though, the effective alphabet size decreases, and as γ→∞→𝛾\gamma\rightarrow\infty, m→n→𝑚𝑛m\rightarrow n. The redundancy rate increases due to the slow decay. For γ≥1𝛾1\gamma\geq 1, it is O​(n5/7​(log⁡n)2/n)𝑂superscript𝑛57superscript𝑛2𝑛O\left(n^{5/7}(\log n)^{2}/n\right). As γ→∞→𝛾\gamma\rightarrow\infty, since the distribution tends to decay faster, the redundancy rate tends to the finite alphabet rate of O​(n1/3​(log⁡n)2/n)𝑂superscript𝑛13superscript𝑛2𝑛O\left(n^{1/3}(\log n)^{2}/n\right). However, as the decay rate is slower γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\rightarrow 0, a non-diminishing redundancy rate is approached. Note that the proof of Theorem 6 does not limit the distribution to a finite entropy one. Therefore, the bound of (89) applies, in fact, also to −1<γ≤01𝛾0-1<\gamma\leq 0. However, for γ≤0𝛾0\gamma\leq 0, the per-symbol redundancy is no long diminishing.

6 Individual Sequences

In this section, we first show that individual sequences whose empirical distributions obey the monotonicity constraints can be universally compressed as well as the average case. We then study compression of sequences whose empirical distributions may diverge from monotonic. We demonstrate that under mild conditions, similar in nature to those of Theorems 5 and 6, redundancy that diminishes (slower than in the average case) w.r.t. the monotonic ML description length can be obtained. However, these results are only useful when the monotonic ML description length diverges only slightly from the (standard) ML description length of a sequence, i.e., the empirical distribution of a sequence only mildly violates monotonicity. Otherwise, the penalty of using an incorrect monotone model overwhelms the redundancy gain. We begin with sequences that obey the monotonicity constraints.

Theorem 7

Fix an arbitrarily small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Let xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} be a sequence for which 𝛉^∈ℳ^𝛉ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}\in{\cal M}, i.e., θ^1≥θ^2≥…subscript^𝜃1subscript^𝜃2…\hat{\theta}_{1}\geq\hat{\theta}_{2}\geq\ldots. Let k=k^𝑘^𝑘k=\hat{k} be the number of letters occurring in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. Then, there exists a code L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}\left(\cdot\right) that achieves individual sequence redundancy w.r.t. 𝛉^ℳ=𝛉^subscript^𝛉ℳ^𝛉\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}=\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} for xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} which is upper bounded by

R^n​(L∗,xn)≤{(1+ε)​k−12​n​log⁡n​(log⁡n)2k3,for ​k≤n1/3,(1+ε)​(log⁡n)​(log⁡kn1/3−ε)​n1/3n,for ​n1/3<k=o​(n),(1+ε)​13​(log⁡n)2​n1/3n,for ​n1/3<k=O​(n).subscript^𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿superscript𝑥𝑛cases1𝜀𝑘12𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛2superscript𝑘3for 𝑘superscript𝑛131𝜀𝑛𝑘superscript𝑛13𝜀superscript𝑛13𝑛for superscript𝑛13𝑘𝑜𝑛1𝜀13superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛13𝑛for superscript𝑛13𝑘𝑂𝑛\hat{R}_{n}\left(L^{*},x^{n}\right)\leq\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{k-1}{2n}\log\frac{n\left(\log n\right)^{2}}{k^{3}},&\mbox{for }k\leq n^{1/3},\\ \left(1+\varepsilon\right)\left(\log n\right)\left(\log\frac{k}{n^{1/3-\varepsilon}}\right)\frac{n^{1/3}}{n},&\mbox{for }n^{1/3}<k=o(n),\\ \left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{1}{3}\left(\log n\right)^{2}\frac{n^{1/3}}{n},&\mbox{for }n^{1/3}<k=O(n).\end{array}\right. (90)

Note that by the monotonicity constraint, the number of symbols k^^𝑘\hat{k} occurring in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} also equals to the maximal symbol in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. Since, in the individual sequence case, this maximal symbol defines the class considered and also to be consistent with Theorem 3, we use k𝑘k to characterize the alphabet size of a given sequence. (The maximal symbol in the individual sequence case is equivalent to the alphabet size in the average case.) Finally, since 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} is monotonic, 𝜽^ℳ=𝜽^subscript^𝜽ℳ^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}=\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}.

Proof of Theorem 7: The result in Theorem 7 follows directly from the proof of Theorem 4. Both regions of the proof apply here, where instead of quantizing 𝜽𝜽\theta to 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}, we quantize 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} to 𝜽^′superscript^𝜽′\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}^{\prime} in a similar manner, and do not need to average over all sequences. In fact, instead of using any general 𝝋^^𝝋\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\varphi$}} to code xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, we can use 𝜽^′superscript^𝜽′\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}^{\prime} without any additional optimizations, where log⁡n𝑛\log n bits describe k𝑘k. The description costs of 𝜽^′superscript^𝜽′\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}^{\prime} are almost the same as those of 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}. The factor 222 reduction in the last region is because it is sufficient here to replace n2superscript𝑛2n^{2} by n𝑛n in the denominators of (41). This is because for every occurring symbol θ^i′≥1/nsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃′𝑖1𝑛\hat{\theta}^{\prime}_{i}\geq 1/n and δi≤1/nsubscript𝛿𝑖1𝑛\delta_{i}\leq 1/n, thus the first term of step (a)𝑎(a) in (50) holds with the new grid, and B2subscript𝐵2B_{2} in (45) reduces by a factor of 222. The quantization costs bounded in (37) and (50) are thus bounded similarly, where 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} replaces 𝜽𝜽\theta and 𝜽^′superscript^𝜽′\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}^{\prime} replaces 𝜽′superscript𝜽′\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}. This results in the bounds in (90) and concludes the proof of Theorem 7. □□\Box

If one a-priori knows that xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} is likely to have been generated by a monotonic distribution, the case considered in Theorem 7 is with high probability the typical one. However, a typical sequence can also be one for which 𝜽^∉ℳ^𝜽ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}\not\in{\cal M}, where 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} mildly violates the monotonicity. In the pure individual sequence setting (where no underlying distribution is assumed but some monotonicity assumption is reasonable for the empirical distribution of xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}), one can still observe sequences that have empirical distributions that are either monotonic or slightly diverge from monotonic. Coding for this more general case can apply the methods described in Section 5 to the individual sequence case. If the divergence from monotonicity is small, one may still achieve bounds of the same order of those presented in Theorem 7 with additional negligible cost of relaying which symbols are out of order. The next theorem, however, provides a general upper bound in the form of the bounds of Theorems 5 and 6 for the individual sequence redundancy w.r.t. the monotonic ML description length, as defined in (10). We begin, again, with some notation.

Recall the definition of an effective alphabet size m=△mρ=△nρsuperscript△𝑚subscript𝑚𝜌superscript△superscript𝑛𝜌m\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}m_{\rho}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}n^{\rho} (where ρ=(log⁡m)/(log⁡n)𝜌𝑚𝑛\rho=(\log m)/(\log n).) Now, use this definition for a specific individual sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. Let

ℛ^n​(m)=△{m−12​log⁡nm,m≤n1/3,m​log⁡nm2,n1/3<m=o​(n),minα<ρ⁡{ρ+1+α2​(ρ−α)​(log⁡n)2​nα+3​(log⁡e)​n1−α},otherwise.superscript△subscript^ℛ𝑛𝑚cases𝑚12𝑛𝑚𝑚superscript𝑛13𝑚𝑛superscript𝑚2superscript𝑛13𝑚𝑜𝑛subscript𝛼𝜌𝜌1𝛼2𝜌𝛼superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛𝛼3𝑒superscript𝑛1𝛼otherwise\hat{{\cal R}}_{n}(m)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{m-1}{2}\log\frac{n}{m},&m\leq n^{1/3},\\ m\log\frac{n}{m^{2}},&n^{1/3}<m=o\left(\sqrt{n}\right),\\ \min_{\alpha<\rho}\left\{\frac{\rho+1+\alpha}{2}\left(\rho-\alpha\right)\left(\log n\right)^{2}n^{\alpha}+3(\log e)n^{1-\alpha}\right\},&\mbox{otherwise}.\end{array}\right. (91)
Theorem 8

Fix an arbitrarily small ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, and let n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. Then, there exists a code with length function L∗​(⋅)superscript𝐿⋅L^{*}(\cdot), that achieves individual sequence redundancy w.r.t. the monotonic ML description length of xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} (as defined in (10)) bounded by

R^n​(L∗,xn)≤1+εn​minρ⁡{ℛ^n​(nρ)+(1+1ρ)​∑i>nρ,i∈xnlog⁡i}subscript^𝑅𝑛superscript𝐿superscript𝑥𝑛1𝜀𝑛subscript𝜌subscript^ℛ𝑛superscript𝑛𝜌11𝜌subscriptformulae-sequence𝑖superscript𝑛𝜌𝑖superscript𝑥𝑛𝑖\hat{R}_{n}\left(L^{*},x^{n}\right)\leq\frac{1+\varepsilon}{n}\min_{\rho}\left\{\hat{{\cal R}}_{n}\left(n^{\rho}\right)+\left(1+\frac{1}{\rho}\right)\sum_{i>n^{\rho},i\in x^{n}}\log i\right\} (92)

for every xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}.

Theorem 8 shows that if one can find a relatively small effective alphabet of the symbols that occur in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, and the symbols outside this alphabet are small enough, xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} can be described with diminishing per-symbol redundancy w.r.t. its monotonic ML description length. This implies that as long as the occurring symbols are not too large, there exist a universal code w.r.t. a monotonic ML distribution for any such sequence xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. This is unlike standard individual sequence compression w.r.t. the i.i.d. ML description length. Specifically, if the effective alphabet size is O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n), and only a small number of symbols which are only polynomial in n𝑛n occur, the universality cost is O​(n​(log⁡n)2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝑛2O(\sqrt{n}(\log n)^{2}) bits overall, which gives diminishing per-symbol redundancy of O​((log⁡n)2/n)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑛O((\log n)^{2}/\sqrt{n}). This redundancy is much better than what can be achieved in standard compression. The penalty, of course, is when the empirical distribution of an individual sequence diverges significantly away from a monotonic one. While the monotonic redundancy can be made diminishing under mild conditions, there is a non-diminishing divergence cost by using the monotonic ML description length instead of the ML description length in that case. This implies that one should compress a sequence as generated by a monotonic distribution only if the total description length required to code xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} as such is shorter than the total description length required to code xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} with standard methods. As shown in the proof of Theorem 8, one prefix bit can inform the decoder which type of description is used.

Theorem 8 shows that as long as the effective alphabet size is polynomial in n𝑛n, α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 optimizes the third region of the upper bound, thus yielding the rate shown above, unless very large symbols occur in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. For small effective alphabets (the first region), there is no redundancy gain in using the monotonic ML description length over the ML description length. The reason, again, is that the bound is obtained for cases where the actual empirical distribution of a sequence may not be monotonic. One can still use an i.i.d. ML estimate w.r.t. only the effective alphabet, if the additional cost of symbols outside this alphabet is negligible, to better code such sequences. Theorem 8 also shows that if a very large symbol, such as i=an𝑖superscript𝑎𝑛i=a^{n}; a>1𝑎1a>1, occurs in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} cannot be universally compressed even w.r.t. its monotonic ML description length. This is because it is impossible to avoid the cost of (1+ε)​log⁡i=(1+ε)​n​log⁡a1𝜀𝑖1𝜀𝑛𝑎(1+\varepsilon)\log i=(1+\varepsilon)n\log a bits to describe this symbol to the decoder. The bound above and its proof below give a very powerful method to individually compress sequences that have an almost monotonic empirical distribution but may have some limited disorder, for which the monotonic ML description length diverges only negligibly from the ML description length.

Proof of Theorem 8: The proof follows the same steps as the proof of Theorems 5 and 6. Each value of m𝑚m is tested and the best one is chosen, where the same coding costs described in the mentioned proof are computed for each m𝑚m. In addition, one can test the cost of coding xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} using the description lengths for both 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} and 𝜽^ℳsubscript^𝜽ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}. Then, one bit can be used to relay which ML estimator is used. If 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} is used, the codes for coding individual sequences over large alphabets in either [21] or [25] can be used. In the first region in (92), the bound in [25] is obtained since log⁡Pθ^​(xn)≥log⁡Pθ^ℳ​(xn)subscript𝑃^𝜃superscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑃subscript^𝜃ℳsuperscript𝑥𝑛\log P_{\hat{\theta}}\left(x^{n}\right)\geq\log P_{\hat{\theta}_{{\cal M}}}\left(x^{n}\right) for every xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. This bound yields smaller redundancy for this region than that obtained using 𝜽^ℳsubscript^𝜽ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}} if 𝜽^ℳ≠𝜽^subscript^𝜽ℳ^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}\neq\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}. It implies that for small alphabets, if xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n} does not have an empirical monotonic distribution, it is better coded, even in terms of universal coding redundancy, using standard universal compression methods without taking advantage of a monotonicity assumption.

For the other two regions, we start with a lemma.

Let 𝛉^ℳ=(θ^1,ℳ,θ^2,ℳ,…,θ^k,ℳ)subscript^𝛉ℳsubscript^𝜃1ℳsubscript^𝜃2ℳ…subscript^𝜃𝑘ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}=\left(\hat{\theta}_{1,{\cal M}},\hat{\theta}_{2,{\cal M}},\ldots,\hat{\theta}_{k,{\cal M}}\right) be the monotonic ML estimator of 𝛉𝛉\theta from xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, i.e., θ^1,ℳ≥θ^2,ℳ≥⋯≥θ^k,ℳsubscript^𝜃1ℳsubscript^𝜃2ℳ⋯subscript^𝜃𝑘ℳ\hat{\theta}_{1,{\cal M}}\geq\hat{\theta}_{2,{\cal M}}\geq\cdots\geq\hat{\theta}_{k,{\cal M}}, where k=max⁡{x1,x2,…,xn}𝑘subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛k=\max\left\{x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}\right\}. This bound helps in designing the grid of points used to quantize the monotonic ML distribution of xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}, while maintaining bounded quantization costs. The proof of Lemma 6.1 is in Appendix C.

Note that this bound also applies to the first region, but in that region, a tighter bound is obtained by using a code that uses the standard i.i.d. ML estimator 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}. This is because very fine quantization is needed to offset the cost of mismatch between 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} and 𝜽^ℳsubscript^𝜽ℳ\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}. This quantization requires higher description costs than the description of a quantized type of a sequence when using standard compression. (This is not the case when 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} obeys the monotonicity, as in Theorem 7. Even if 𝜽^^𝜽\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} does not obey monotonicity in the upper regions of the bound, this is not the case.)

For the last region of the bound, we follow the same steps above as was done for the upper region of the bound in Theorem 5 with a parameter α𝛼\alpha. The intervals are chosen, again, to guarantee bounded quantization costs. Hence,

quantization points. Using the same methodology as in (67), this yields a representation cost of

LR​(𝝋m)≤(1+ε)​ρ+1+α2​(ρ+ε−α)​(log⁡n)2​nα.subscript𝐿𝑅subscript𝝋𝑚1𝜀𝜌1𝛼2𝜌𝜀𝛼superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛𝛼L_{R}\left(\mbox{\boldmath$\varphi$}_{m}\right)\leq\left(1+\varepsilon\right)\frac{\rho+1+\alpha}{2}\left(\rho+\varepsilon-\alpha\right)(\log n)^{2}n^{\alpha}. (102)

where (a)𝑎(a) follows from similar steps to (a)𝑎(a)-(c)𝑐(c) of (98). Using Lemma 6.1, φi,m≥1/nρ+1subscript𝜑𝑖𝑚1superscript𝑛𝜌1\varphi_{i,m}\geq 1/n^{\rho+1} and |δi|≤1/nρ+1+αsubscript𝛿𝑖1superscript𝑛𝜌1𝛼|\delta_{i}|\leq 1/n^{\rho+1+\alpha}, leading to the first term. Bounding |δi|≤nj​β/nρ+1+2​αsubscript𝛿𝑖superscript𝑛𝑗𝛽superscript𝑛𝜌12𝛼|\delta_{i}|\leq n^{j\beta}/n^{\rho+1+2\alpha} and φi,m≥n(j−1)​β/nρ+1+αsubscript𝜑𝑖𝑚superscript𝑛𝑗1𝛽superscript𝑛𝜌1𝛼\varphi_{i,m}\geq n^{(j-1)\beta}/n^{\rho+1+\alpha} leads to the second term. Note that as before, m𝑚m is used here in place of k𝑘k, because using an effective alphabet m𝑚m, all greater symbols are packed together as one symbol, and the additional cost to describe them is reflected in an additional term. Adding this additional term with an identical expression to that in the lower regions, absorbing low order terms in ε𝜀\varepsilon, and normalizing by n𝑛n, yields the third region of the bound in (92). Since the bound holds for every α𝛼\alpha and every ρ>α𝜌𝛼\rho>\alpha, it can be optimized to give the values that attain the minimum, concluding the proof of Theorem 8. □□\Box

7 Summary and Conclusions

Universal compression of sequences generated by monotonic distributions was studied. We showed that for finite alphabets, if one has the prior knowledge of the monotonicity of a distribution, one can reduce the cost of universality. For alphabets of o​(n1/3)𝑜superscript𝑛13o(n^{1/3}) letters, this cost reduces from 0.5​log⁡(n/k)0.5𝑛𝑘0.5\log(n/k) bits per each unknown probability parameter to 0.5​log⁡(n/k3)0.5𝑛superscript𝑘30.5\log(n/k^{3}) bits per each unknown probability parameter. Otherwise, for alphabets of O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) letters, one can compress such sources with overall redundancy of O​(n1/3+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits. This is a significant decrease in redundancy from O​(k​log⁡n)𝑂𝑘𝑛O(k\log n) or O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) bits overall that can be achieved if no side information is available about the source distribution. Redundancy of O​(n1/3+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛13𝜀O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits overall can also be achieved for much larger alphabets including infinite alphabets for fast decaying monotonic distributions. Sequences generated by slower decaying distributions can also be compressed with diminishing per-symbol redundancy costs under some mild conditions and specifically if they have finite entropy rates. Examples for well-known monotonic distributions demonstrated how the diminishing redundancy decay rates can be computed by applying the bounds that were derived. Finally, the average case results were extended to individual sequences. Similar convergence rates were shown for sequences that have empirical monotonic distributions. Furthermore, universal redundancy bounds w.r.t. the monotonic ML description length of a sequence were also derived for the more general case. Under some mild conditions, these bounds still exhibit diminishing per-symbol redundancies.

Appendix Appendix A –   Proof of Theorem 1

The proof follows the same steps used in [25] and [26] to lower bound the maximin redundancies for large alphabets and patterns, respectively, using the weak version of the redundancy-capacity theorem [5]. This version ties between the maximin universal coding redundancy and the capacity of a channel defined by the conditional probability Pθ​(xn)subscript𝑃𝜃superscript𝑥𝑛P_{\theta}\left(x^{n}\right). We define a set 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} of points 𝜽∈ℳk𝜽subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}_{k}. Then, show that these points are distinguishable by observing Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}, i.e., the probability that Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} generated by 𝜽∈𝛀ℳk𝜽subscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} appears to have been generated by another point 𝜽′∈𝛀ℳksuperscript𝜽′subscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}\in\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} diminishes with n𝑛n. Then, using Fano’s inequality [3], the number of such distinguishable points is a lower bound on Rn−​(ℳk)superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛subscriptℳ𝑘R_{n}^{-}\left({\cal M}_{k}\right). Since Rn+​(ℳk)≥Rn−​(ℳk)superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛subscriptℳ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛subscriptℳ𝑘R_{n}^{+}\left({\cal M}_{k}\right)\geq R_{n}^{-}\left({\cal M}_{k}\right), it is also a lower bound on the average minimax redundancy. The two regions in (6) result from a threshold phenomenon, where there exists a value kmsubscript𝑘𝑚k_{m} of k𝑘k that maximizes the lower bound, and can be applied to all ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k} for k≥km𝑘subscript𝑘𝑚k\geq k_{m}.

Appendix Appendix B –   Proof of Theorem 2

To prove Theorem 2, we use the random-coding strong version of the redundancy-capacity theorem [17]. The idea is similar to the weak version used in Appendix A. We assume that grids 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} of points are uniformly distributed over ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}, and one grid is selected randomly. Then, a point in the selected grid is randomly selected under a uniform prior to generate Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}. Showing distinguishability within a selected grid, for every possible random choice of 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, implies that a lower bound on the cardinality of 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} for every possible choice is essentially a lower bound on the overall sequence redundancy for most sources in ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}.

The construction of 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} is identical to that used in [26] to construct a grid of sources that generate patterns. We pack spheres of radius n−0.5​(1−ε)superscript𝑛0.51𝜀n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)} in the parameter space defining ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}. The set 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} consists of the center points of the spheres. To cover the space ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}, we randomly select a random shift of the whole lattice under a uniform distribution. The cardinality of 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} is lower bounded by the relation between the volume of ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}, which equals (as shown in [26]) 1/[(k−1)!​k!]1delimited-[]𝑘1𝑘1/[(k-1)!k!], and the volume of a single sphere, with factoring also of a packing density (see, e.g., [2]). This yields eq. (55) in [26],

Mℳk≥1(k−1)!⋅k!⋅Vk−1​(n−0.5​(1−ε))⋅2k−1,subscript𝑀subscriptℳ𝑘1⋅⋅𝑘1𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘1superscript𝑛0.51𝜀superscript2𝑘1M_{{\cal M}_{k}}\geq\frac{1}{(k-1)!\cdot k!\cdot V_{k-1}\left(n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)}\right)\cdot 2^{k-1}}, (B.1)

where Vk−1​(n−0.5​(1−ε))subscript𝑉𝑘1superscript𝑛0.51𝜀V_{k-1}\left(n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)}\right) is the volume of a k−1𝑘1k-1 dimensional sphere with radius n−0.5​(1−ε)superscript𝑛0.51𝜀n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)} (see, e.g., [2] for computation of this volume).

For distinguishability, it is sufficient to show that there exists an estimator 𝚯^g​(Xn)∈𝛀ℳksubscript^𝚯𝑔superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}}_{g}(X^{n})\in\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} such that limn→∞PΘ​[𝚯^g​(Xn)≠𝚯]=0subscript→𝑛subscript𝑃Θdelimited-[]subscript^𝚯𝑔superscript𝑋𝑛𝚯0\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}P_{\Theta}\left[\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}}_{g}(X^{n})\neq\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}\right]=0 for every choice of 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} and for every choice of 𝚯∈𝛀ℳk𝚯subscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}\in\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}. This is already shown in Lemma 4.1 in [25] for a larger grid 𝛀𝛀\Omega of i.i.d. sources, which is constructed identically to 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} over the complete k−1𝑘1k-1 dimensional probability simplex. Therefore, by the monotonicity requirement, for every 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, there exists such 𝛀𝛀\Omega, such that 𝛀ℳk⊆𝛀subscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘𝛀\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}\subseteq\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}. Since Lemma 4.1 in [25] holds for 𝛀𝛀\Omega, it then must also hold for the smaller grid 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}. Note that distinguishability is easier to prove here than for patterns because 𝚯^g​(Xn)subscript^𝚯𝑔superscript𝑋𝑛\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}}_{g}(X^{n}) is obtained directly form Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} and not from its pattern as in [26]. Now, since all the conditions of the strong random-coding version of the redundancy-capacity theorem hold, taking the logarithm of bound in (B.1), absorbing low order terms in ε𝜀\varepsilon, and normalizing by n𝑛n, leads to the first region of the bound in (7). More detailed steps follow those found in [26].

The second region of the bound is handled in a manner related to the second region of the bound of Theorem 1. However, here, we cannot simply set the probability of all symbols i>km𝑖subscript𝑘𝑚i>k_{m} to zero, because all possible valid sources must be included in one of the grids 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} to generate a complete covering of ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k}. As was done in [26], we include sources with θi>0subscript𝜃𝑖0\theta_{i}>0 for i>km𝑖subscript𝑘𝑚i>k_{m} in the grids 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, but do not include them in the lower bound on the number of grid points. Instead, for k>km𝑘subscript𝑘𝑚k>k_{m}, we bound the number of points in a kmsubscript𝑘𝑚k_{m}-dimensional cut of ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘{\cal M}_{k} for which the remaining k−km𝑘subscript𝑘𝑚k-k_{m} components of 𝜽𝜽\theta are very small (and insignificant). This analysis is valid also for k>n𝑘𝑛k>n. Distinguishability for k>km𝑘subscript𝑘𝑚k>k_{m} is shown for i.i.d. non-monotonically restricted distributions in the proof of Lemma 6.1 in [26]. As before, it carries over to monotonic distributions, since as before, for each 𝛀ℳksubscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, there exists an unrestricted corresponding 𝛀𝛀\Omega, such that 𝛀ℳk⊆𝛀subscript𝛀subscriptℳ𝑘𝛀\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}\subseteq\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}. The choice of km=0.5​(n1−ε/π)1/3subscript𝑘𝑚0.5superscriptsuperscript𝑛1𝜀𝜋13k_{m}=0.5(n^{1-\varepsilon}/\pi)^{1/3} gives the maximal bound w.r.t. k𝑘k. Since, again, all conditions of the strong version of the redundancy-capacity theorem are satisfied, the second region of the bound is obtained. Again, more detailed steps can be found in [26]. This concludes the proof of Theorem 2. □□\Box

where we recall that nx​(i)subscript𝑛𝑥𝑖n_{x}(i) is the occurrence count of i𝑖i in xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}.
